content.question: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations. A physician at a large health clinic believes that the amount of water that the <math alttext="750" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>750</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> patients of the clinic drink, on average, per day is different from <math alttext="64" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>64</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ounces. A random sample of <math alttext="40" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> patients from the clinic were surveyed with the following question. How many ounces of water do you usually drink per day? From the <math alttext="40" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> respondents, the physician obtained a one-sample <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-interval to estimate <math alttext="mu sub W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, the mean amount of water, in ounces, that all patients of the clinic drink per day. Assume the conditions for inference have been met. At the <math alttext="96" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>96</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent confidence level, the interval was <math alttext="52.531 plus or minus 5.150" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>52.531</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>5.150</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Does the confidence interval support the physician’s belief that the amount of water that all patients of the clinic drink, on average, per day is different from <math alttext="64" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>64</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ounces? Justify your answer.

frqParts.text: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations. A physician at a large health clinic believes that the amount of water that the <math alttext="750" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>750</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> patients of the clinic drink, on average, per day is different from <math alttext="64" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>64</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ounces. A random sample of <math alttext="40" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> patients from the clinic were surveyed with the following question. How many ounces of water do you usually drink per day? From the <math alttext="40" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> respondents, the physician obtained a one-sample <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-interval to estimate <math alttext="mu sub W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, the mean amount of water, in ounces, that all patients of the clinic drink per day. Assume the conditions for inference have been met. At the <math alttext="96" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>96</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent confidence level, the interval was <math alttext="52.531 plus or minus 5.150" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>52.531</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>5.150</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Does the confidence interval support the physician’s belief that the amount of water that all patients of the clinic drink, on average, per day is different from <math alttext="64" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>64</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ounces? Justify your answer.

Upon further investigation, the physician believes that younger patients (under <math alttext="40" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> years of age) may respond differently to the survey than older patients (<math alttext="40" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> or more years of age). The physician plans to conduct a new survey using independent random samples of younger patients and older patients. Assume that there are approximately equal numbers of younger patients and older patients at the clinic.(b) Describe a method that the physician could use to obtain two independent random samples, one of <math alttext="18" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>18</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> younger patients and one of <math alttext="14" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>14</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> older patients, from the <math alttext="750" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>750</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> patients of the clinic.

(c) The physician wants to use an inference procedure to determine whether the sample data provide convincing statistical evidence of a difference in the population mean amounts of water, in ounces, that younger patients and older patients would drink per day. Explain whether each condition for inference is met.

The physician decided to also ask each patient in the new survey to report the amount of sodium, in milligrams, they consume each day. The scatterplot below shows the data for each of the patients in the two samples. (d) Describe what the scatterplot reveals about the relationship between amount of sodium per day and amount of water per day for each of the following: the <math alttext="18" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>18</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> younger patients and the <math alttext="14" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>14</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> older patients.

A scatterplot of only the <math alttext="18" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>18</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> younger patients is shown, along with regression output for a linear model using amount of sodium per day to predict amount of water per day. The circled point on the scatterplot represents a patient who reported <math alttext="2,725" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mtext>,725</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> milligrams of sodium per day and <math alttext="41" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>41</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ounces of water per day. (e) Describe the impact on the slope of the least-squares regression line and the coefficient of determination, <math alttext="r squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, if the circled point was removed from the data. Explain your answer.

skill.text: Skill 1.C: Describe an appropriate method for gathering and representing data.
